con.para: Work in physics happens when you use force to move something! For example, pushing a box across the floor is work, but just standing still isn’t.
When you do work, you’re transferring energy. Pushing, pulling, lifting—these actions use energy and transfer it to the object you're moving.
Power is how quickly work is done. If two people move the same box, the one who moves it faster uses more power.
Simple machines make work easier! They help you use less force to move heavy objects. There are six types of simple machines. Let's explore them!
A lever is a simple machine that uses a bar and a fulcrum (pivot point). You can lift heavy things by pushing down on one side of the lever.
A pulley is a wheel with a rope. Pulling the rope down lifts objects up! Pulleys help lift heavy objects, like a flag or bucket of water.
An inclined plane is like a ramp. It helps move objects up without lifting them straight up. Pushing a box up a ramp is easier than lifting it!
A screw is an inclined plane wrapped around a cylinder. Screws help hold things together or move objects up slowly, like in a screw jack.
A wedge is like two inclined planes back to back. It’s used to split things apart, like an axe splitting wood or a doorstop holding a door open.
A wheel and axle is a simple machine that makes it easier to move things. The wheel turns, and the axle helps reduce the force needed to move objects.
Simple machines give us a "mechanical advantage," meaning they help us use less effort to do the same amount of work. The right tool makes a big difference!
Simple machines are all around us! From scissors (a lever) to bikes (wheel and axle), they make everyday tasks easier. Can you find them in your home?
